reference:
Data are randomly sampled from the TV16 data set in the same package
for the age, female, college education, family income, and born-again variables.
Thereafter, I created an arbitrary "happiness" variable that is equal to
100 -  .95*age + .01*(age^2) + .25*female + .05*famincr + .1*bornagain + e. The
data are not supposed to be realistic, per se. They're supposed to be functional for this
purpose.
description:
Description
This is a toy ("fake") data set I might use to illustrate the so-called
curvilinear effect of age on happiness.
title: Fake Data on Happiness

parameters.bornagain: a numeric vector for whether the respondent self-identifies as a born-again Christian.
parameters.female: a numeric that equals 1 if the respondent is a woman
parameters.e: random noise, generated from a normal distribution with a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 3
parameters.z_happy: the same arbitrary happiness variable, scaled to have a mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1. This makes it seem more "latent".
parameters.happy: an arbitrary happiness variable. See details for its construction
parameters.collegeed: a numeric vector that equals 1 if the respondent says s/he has a college degree
parameters.famincr: a numeric vector for the respondent's household income. Ranges from 1 to 12.

format: A data frame with 1000 observations on the following 8 variables.
